PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no family unit which is raised on pioneer land has the same experiences as another. Some of them have never been away from their homes; others may have moved several times. It is not easy for your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events. If they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer diet
( ) Pioneer schools
( ) Pioneer churches
( ) Pioneer recreation and social life
( ) Pioneer farming experiences
( ) Folklore in Saskatchewan
( ) Pioneer health and housing

Presentation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it will necessarily be able to answer all questions. It may be necessary to use more than one sheet of paper in order to answer all questions. The extra sheets of paper, if there are not sufficient space to answer the questions, should be used.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

1. Your full name: Rolland Mr. Mcneigh
2. Your address: 1112. North St. Paul, Battleford, Sask.
3. Date: January 16, 1955
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Sheffield, England
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Joseph, Hall, miller or Canada farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): March 1903
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan:
   River settlement near Athabasca north west of Saskatchewan
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child"). I was in my teens, etc.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   A liking for adventure and a belief in better living
   Improved me in our country, such as Canada.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroads or government information?) Reading homestead, frontier books etc. and partly through a conversation with a farmer from Manitoba.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

People were moving very much faster then moving out of Northfield and new district.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

To my knowledge there was very little fluctuation

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible.

A brother-in-law served also as President of the Board of Education.

Office in Ashburnham Bridge #17, S.O.A. as mentioned.

Office in Ashburnham Town Hall until the present time.

For more than 20 years on the Board of Education.

Also active in Ashburnham Town from 1939 to 1948.

My father, Ambulance Driver.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were interested to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates whenever possible (such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

I was the first township constable for the village of Northfield in 1906.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railroad stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in name since the first name; (5) reason for change.

Northfield, which was named I understand because of battle with the Cree Indians and a ford across the river at that point. Rockfield Lake and creek north of town before the town existed because of the lack of good fish at cornfields. Also Rockfield would not catch because of its peculiar sound. Also after which the municipality of Rockfield was named. Northfield Lake also became of a familiar sound in the surrounding area.
31. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

People were moving for very much faster than moving by horse and buggy.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

To my knowledge there was very little fluctuation.

36. If yes or no, members of your family have held public offices or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible.

A brother-in-law served as a member of the Board of Education.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were affiliated with any organization (such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc.), I may be the first member of the village of North Battleford in 1906.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.)

Try to give (1) name and occupation, (2) reason for its adoption, (3) any changes in name since the first name was given, date and reason for change, (4) fate of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

North Battleford which was named in honor of the old settlement because of battle with the Cree Indians over a food source.
